TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: ka sitsuayan izua ti sa Tjukutjuku.
ka sicoayan izoa ti sa Tjokotjoko.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there was a woman called Tjukutjuku.

S.FORM: qau mapu tua ḍipupun katua aluvetjułatan, sa vaik a sema tjatjan.
qao mapo toa dripopon katoa alovetjoljatan, sa vaik a sema tjatjan.
S.TRANSL: She chewed the nuts of the ḍipupun and aluvetjułatan trees, and went to the spring.

S.FORM: qau sidjilay i tjatjan azua inapuan.
qao sidjilay i tjatjan azoa inapoan.
S.TRANSL: She spat into the spring what she had chewed;

S.FORM: qau sa tsemuvuq azua djilay tua saviki.
qao sa cemovoq azoa djilay toa saviki.
S.TRANSL: and the spit sprouted into an areca tree.

S.FORM: qau meqatsa azua saviki, venangał.
qao meqaca azoa saviki, venangalj.
S.TRANSL: The areca tree got bigger and bore fruit;

S.FORM: qau kisavikin anga ni sa Tjukutjuku tu apuin.
qao kisavikin anga ni sa Tjokotjoko to apoin.
S.TRANSL: and Tjukutjuku got areca nuts from it to chew.

S.FORM: azua ti sa Tjukutjuku ka vaik a kivala sema zua itjua tapaw nua mareqali, inika pinalimasudj a tapaw.
azoa ti sa Tjokotjoko ka vaik a kivala sema zoa itjoa tapaw noa mareqali, inika pinalimasodj a tapaw.
S.TRANSL: When Tjukutjuku went to amuse herself to the house of some men friends, the house had not been tidied.

S.FORM: qau suapan ni sa Tjukutjuku; sa tjangtjangan ta saviki, sa vaik a tsemikel a tjumaq.
qao soapan ni sa Tjokotjoko; sa tjangtjangan ta saviki, sa vaik a cemikel a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: Tjukutjuku swept the house, and left some crushed and prepared areca nuts, and went back home.

S.FORM: mangtjez a mareqali.
mangtjez a mareqali.
"łaqa, tima nasemuap tua tja tapaw?
"ljaqa, tima nasemoap toa tja tapaw?
S.TRANSL: “What’s this? Who has swept our house?

S.FORM: tjamanguaq a tja raungen," aya.
tjamangoaq a tja raongen," aya.
S.TRANSL: It would be better if we laid in wait for them,” they said.

S.FORM: qau raungen nua mareqali.
qao raongen noa mareqali.
S.TRANSL: So the men friends lay in wait.

S.FORM: manu mangtjez azua ti sa Tjukutjuku.
mano mangtjez azoa ti sa Tjokotjoko.
qau puvałavan anga nua mareqali, aya a tjautsikel.
qao povaljavan anga noa mareqali, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: and she became the wife of (one of?) the men friends, according to the story.

S.FORM: saka mavan nu sika izua nua saviki.
saka mavan no sika izoa noa saviki.
S.TRANSL: And that’s the reason why there are areca trees now.
